facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 134 to 137 of 1959 were filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 134 to 137 of 1959. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 20,1957, of the Bombay High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 14 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated September 20, 1957 of Bombay High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 14 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 20,1957, of the Bombay High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 14 of 1957. RJ. Kolah, S. N. Andley, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 3, 1961 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. This judgment governs the disposal of Civil Appeals Nos. 134 to 137 of 1959.

facts.text: Four appeals filed by four assessees arising out of similar facts.

anchor.surface_text: This judgment governs the disposal of Civil Appeals Nos. 134 to 137 of 1959. They have been filed by four assessees with special leave, and arise out of similar facts, and it is number necessary to refer to more than one case to companysider the point in question.

facts.text: Assessment year is 1952-53, previous year is calendar year 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment year under companysideration is 1952-53, and the previous year, the Calendar year, 1951. In that year, Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand, one of the four appellants, made a declaration of trust in favour of his wife,

facts.text: Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand made a declaration of trust dated 5th March 1951 in favour of his wife Vimla.

anchor.surface_text: In that year, Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand, one of the four appellants, made a declaration of trust in favour of his wife, a portion of which may be quoted here 1, Tulsidas Kilachand hereby de- clare that I hold 244 shares of Kesar Corporation Ltd. and 120 shares of Kilachand Devchand Co., Ltd upon trust to pay the income thereof to my wife Vimla for a period of seven years from the date hereof or her death  whichever event may be earlier  and I hereby declare that this trust shall number be revocable.

facts.text: Declaration of trust covers 244 shares of Kesar Corporation Ltd. and 120 shares of Kilachand Devchand Co., Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: 1, Tulsidas Kilachand hereby de- clare that I hold 244 shares of Kesar Corporation Ltd. and 120 shares of Kilachand Devchand Co., Ltd upon trust to pay the income thereof to my wife Vimla for a period of seven years from the date hereof or her death  whichever event may be earlier

facts.text: Trust to pay income to wife Vimla for seven years from date or her death whichever earlier, irrevocable.

anchor.surface_text: upon trust to pay the income thereof to my wife Vimla for a period of seven years from the date hereof or her death  whichever event may be earlier  and I hereby declare that this trust shall number be revocable. In the year of account, a sum of Rs. 30,404 was received as dividend income on those shares,

facts.text: In year of account 1951, Rs. 30,404 received as dividend income on those shares.

anchor.surface_text: In the year of account, a sum of Rs. 30,404 was received as dividend income on those shares, and the assessee companytended that this income, after being grossed up, was number liable to be included in his total income,

facts.text: Assessee contended dividend income not liable to be included in his total income per third proviso to s.16(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: and the assessee companytended that this income, after being grossed up, was number liable to be included in his total income, in view of the third proviso to s. 16 1  c  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer did not accept contention, held income accrued to or arisen in hands of Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand and paid by him to wife.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer did number accept this companytention, and though the assessment order is number before us, we gather from the statement of the case that the reason he gave was that the income had accrued to or had arisen in the hands of Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand and had been paid by him to his wife.

facts.text: ITO held words of proviso 'income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition' did not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer held that the words of the proviso income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition did number apply to this income.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held case governed by s.16(3)(b), not third proviso to s.16(1)(c), appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the case was governed by s. 16 3  b , and need number be companysidered under the third proviso. to s. 16 1  c  of the Act. It appears to have been companyceded before him that if the former provision applied, the proviso would number save the income from being assessed in the hands of Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand. The appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Tribunal held case covered by s.16(3)(a)(iii) or s.16(3)(b), income liable to be included.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the case was companyered either by s. 16 3  a  iii  or by s. 16 3  b , and that the income from the shares was, therefore, liable to be included in the income of Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question under s.66(1) to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, raised and referred the following question under s. 66 1  of the Act to the High Court of Bombay Whether on a true companystruction of the deed of declaration of trust dated 5th March , 1951, the net dividend income of Rs. 30,404 on 120 shares of Kilachand Devchand Co., Ltd. and 244 shares of Kesar Corporation Ltd. held under trust by the assessee for the benefit of his wife was income liable to be included in the total income of the assessee?

facts.text: High Court concluded s.16(1)(c) not satisfied due to third proviso, but s.16(3)(b) applicable, answered question affirmatively.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the companyclusion that, though s. 16 1  c  was number satisfied in view of the third proviso, s. 16 3  b  was applicable to the case, and answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds there was transfer of assets by Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand to himself as trustee for benefit of wife.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there was, in this case, a transfer by Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand to himself as a trustee, though there was numberformal transfer. The assessee also stresses the words any person or association of persons in s. 16 3  b ,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds s.16(3)(b) covers the case.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 16 3  b  companyers the case. It remains to companysider whether there was adequate companysideration for the transfer.

facts.text: No adequate consideration for transfer, love and affection not adequate consideration under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The words adequate companysideration denote Consideration other than mere love and affection, which, in the case of a wife, may be presumed. When the law insists that there should be adequate companysideration and number good companysideration, it excludes mere love and affection.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail, and are dismissed with companyts.

arguments.claim: Legislation designed to prevent tax avoidance by settlements where taxpayer retains interests

anchor.surface_text: The object of framing s. 16 can almost be taken from the observations of Lord Macmillan in Chamberlain v. Inland Revenue Commissioners  1 , where he stated as follows This legislation  is  designed to overtake and circumvent a growing tendency on the part of taxpayers to endeavour to avoid or reduce tax liability by means of settlements.

arguments.claim: s.16(1)(c) applies to income from assets remaining property of settlor or revocable transfer

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 1  c  provides that income from assets remaining the property of the settlor or disponer or arising to any person by virtue of a revocable transfer of assets shall be deemed to be the income of the transferor.

arguments.claim: Provat Kumar Mitter case not applicable as there dividends only assigned, not shares transferred

anchor.surface_text: What cl.  c  means was decided by this Court in Provat Kumar Mitter v. Commissioner of Income-tax  2 . There, Provat Kumar Mitter had assigned the dividends only, and had not transferred the relevant shares. ... That case thus has no application to the facts of the present case, where the disposition is differently made.

arguments.claim: s.16(1)(c) has no application as shares held in trust, do not remain property of settlor; proviso not attracted

arguments.claim: Under ss.5 and 6 Indian Trusts Act, declarer as trustee implies transfer without overt act

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, under ss. 5 and 6 of the Indian Trusts Act if the declarer of the trust is himself the trustee also, there is no need that he must transfer the property to himself as trustee but the law implies that such a transfer has been made by him

arguments.claim: s.16(3)(b) covers the case

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 16 3  b covers the case. It remains to consider whether there was adequate consideration for the transfer.

arguments.claim: No adequate consideration; love and affection not adequate, only good consideration

anchor.surface_text: The words adequate consideration denote Consideration other than mere love and affection, which, in the case of a wife, may be presumed. When the law insists that there should be adequate consideration and not good consideration, it excludes mere love and affection.

holdings.text: Section 16(1)(c) has no application, and the third proviso is not attracted, because by the deed of trust, the settlor holds the shares in trust and the shares do not remain the property of the settlor.

anchor.surface_text: But by the deed of trust, the settlor holds the shares in trust the shares do number remain the property of the settlor. Section 16 1  c  has, therefore, numberapplication, and the proviso is number attracted. The section goes on to deal with other situations and to provide for them specially.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trust declaration divests settlor of personal ownership; assets no longer 'remaining the property of the settlor'; distinguishes Provat Kumar Mitter where only dividends assigned.

holdings.text: There was a transfer of assets by Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand to himself as trustee for the benefit of his wife, though no formal transfer.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there was, in this case, a transfer by Mr. Tulsidas Kilachand to himself as a trustee, though there was numberformal transfer. The assessee also stresses the words any person or association of persons in s. 16 3  b ,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Declaration of trust implies transfer per ss.5-6 Indian Trusts Act; capacity changes from personal to trustee; permitted under Transfer of Property Act.

holdings.text: The word 'any person' in s.16(3)(b) is wide enough to include the husband when he transfers property to himself in trustee capacity.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee also stresses the words any person or association of persons in s. 16 3  b , ... The word any person is wide enough to include the husband, when he transfers property to himself in another capacity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'any person'; change of capacity (personal to trustee) makes transferor and transferee distinct.

holdings.text: s.16(3)(b) covers the case as there was transfer without adequate consideration for benefit of wife.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 16 3  b companyers the case. It remains to companysider whether there was adequate companysideration for the transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines findings of transfer to trustee (self) for wife's benefit without adequate consideration.

holdings.text: There was no adequate consideration for the transfer; 'adequate consideration' denotes consideration other than mere love and affection, which is excluded.

anchor.surface_text: The words adequate companysideration denote Consideration other than mere love and affection, which, in the case of a wife, may be presumed. When the law insists that there should be adequate companysideration and number good companysideration, it excludes mere love and affection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language distinguishes 'adequate' from 'good' consideration; love/affection presumed but insufficient for tax purposes.

holdings.text: The net dividend income was liable to be included in the total income of the assessee; High Court answer correct; appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The answer given by the High Court was thus companyrect. The appeals fail, and are dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.16(3)(b) applies via transfer to self-as-trustee without adequate consideration; s.16(1)(c) inapplicable.
